description: Unknown. Possibly from Middle English askances (“as if”), or from Old French a escone (“hidden”) or Italian a scancio (“obliquely”). Compare asquint, Middle English askoyn (“at a slant, askance”), Dutch schuin, schuins (“sideways”), schuiven (“to shove”), schuinte (“slope”).

entries.meaning: Turned to the side, especially of the eyes.
examples: My first thought was, he lied in every word,That hoary cripple, with malicious eyeAskance to watch the working of his lie

entries.meaning: (of a look or glance) With disapproval, skepticism, or suspicion.
examples: The beggar asked for change, but the haughty woman only looked at him askance.

verbs.description: askance (third-person singular simple present askances, present participle askancing, simple past and past participle askanced)

entries.meaning: (rare, transitive) To look at (someone or something) with a sideways glance.
examples: Bowed heads, Aunt Ellen's, Aunt Laura's, her sister's — bowed but askancing her yellow dress — yes, yellow, golden yellow, hue of sun and life, Dad's favorite, to see him off on this, his greatest journey.

entries.meaning: (rare, transitive) To turn (one's eye or gaze) to the side.
